Foil Index

(Incomplete)
Star Brite Household Foil 1934–1951

Manufactured in Kalamazoo by the Star Brite Metals Co. Thinner gauge than Reynolds, with a distinctive matte finish on one side. Agnes called it "the whisperer" — said it produced the lowest-frequency crinkle of any pre-war brand.

Condition
Stored in nitrogen-sealed bags. Two sheets remain. Do not handle without cotton gloves.
Kitch-o-Matic Wrap-All 1939–1944

Wartime production. The alloy shifted in '42 when tin was rationed — the post-rationing version sounds completely different. Higher pitch, almost musical. Agnes had four sheets from each period.

Condition
Pre-rationing sheets in acid-free tissue. Post-rationing sheets showed micro-fractures as of 2019.
Air Wrap "Supreme" 1937–1946

Chicago-made. The only brand that embossed a tiny logo on each sheet — visible under magnification. Dale Rothinghaus insists the embossing affects the acoustic profile. He may be right. That's the worst part.

Condition
Complete box with original cardboard cutter. Donated by the estate of Myrtle Henshaw, Wheaton, IL.
Reynolds Pre-War Standard 1926–1941

The gold standard. Or silver standard. The alloy composition changed in '38 — this is the heart of the Great Reynolds Conspiracy (see Thread #1177). Agnes's original recording was made with a 1938 sheet.

Condition
The 1938 sheet was with Agnes. Current holdings: three sheets, 1933 and 1936 production runs.
Alcoa Household 1932–1950

Alcoa bought the domain in 2021 and never once asked about the foil. They wanted the name. This is the company that made the alloy in the first place. If that's not a metaphor I don't know what is.

Condition
Five sheets in decent shape. Agnes had the best one.
Miracle Wrap "Everlasting" 1940–1943

Short-lived Ohio brand. The name was aspirational. It lasted three years. But the crinkle was extraordinary — bright and clean, like someone snapping a photo of nothing in particular. Agnes's favorite.

Condition
Last known sheet. Heavy oxidation. Handle only for recording purposes.

The Great Reynolds Conspiracy

Forum Archive, Thread #1177
RE: 1938 Alloy Change — Deliberate or Supply Issue? Started by FoilFanatic_Dale · 47 views · 5 replies
FoilFanatic_Dale Senior Member · 312 posts
Nov 14, 2019, 9:03 PM

I've been saying this for two years and nobody listens. The Reynolds Metals Company changed their household foil alloy in 1938. Not because of supply chain issues. Not because of cost. They changed it because someone told them to.

I have three sheets from '37 and two from '39. The spectrographic analysis is night and day. The '37 has a harmonic frequency at 2.3kHz that completely disappears in '39. That doesn't happen from a minor alloy adjustment. That's a redesign.

The question isn't whether they changed it. The question is who asked them to, and why they never documented it. I've filed four FOIA requests. All denied. "No responsive documents." For a foil company. Think about that.

Last edited: Nov 14, 2019, 11:47 PM
WrapRanger_Bethany Admin · 89 posts
Nov 15, 2019, 7:12 AM

Dale, I love you, but four FOIA requests is a lot of postage for a foil company. That said — the 2.3kHz thing is real. Agnes confirmed it independently with different equipment. So either you're both wrong the same way, or you're both right, which is somehow worse.

MasterOfMalleability_77 Member · 24 posts

Has anyone considered that the '38 change coincides with Reynolds getting a defense contract? They started producing military-grade foil for ration kits. It's possible the household line was just collateral. Changed the factory setup, couldn't easily run two alloy compositions. Occam's razor, people.

FoilFanatic_Dale Senior Member · 312 posts
Nov 16, 2019, 8:17 PM

@MasterOfMalleability_77 — I appreciate the Occam's razor point and I've considered it. But here's the thing: the defense contract was signed in March 1939. The alloy change happened in late 1938. Before the contract. So either Reynolds knew about the contract before it existed — which is its own problem — or the change was for a different reason entirely. I have the production records. I drove to Richmond. I sat in their archive for three days. The gap is real.

Foil Lore

Things People Believe
ENTRY 001
EMF Shielding Properties of Pre-War Alloys
Multiple club members report measurable EMF attenuation when wrapping electronic devices in pre-1941 foil. Dale Rothinghaus claims a 23% reduction using a Star Brite sheet, though his methodology involves a RadioShack meter he bought in 1996 and refuses to replace. Modern foil shows no equivalent effect. Agnes's tests were more rigorous, but the data was on her laptop.
STATUS: UNVERIFIED
ENTRY 002
The 1952 Air Force Foil Memorandum
An alleged USAF internal memo from Wright-Patterson describing acoustic testing of consumer aluminum foil for "signal characteristics." Circulated in the community since at least 2003. The only known copy is a photocopy of a photocopy owned by a man in Akron who won't let anyone scan it. I drove there in 2019. He let me look at it for ten minutes. It looked real. It also looked like it could've been made on a typewriter in a garage.
STATUS: PLAUSIBLE
ENTRY 003
The Roswell Wrapper Fragment
An eBay listing from 2008 claimed to offer "metallic debris consistent with the Roswell recovery" that was, upon testing by two club members, ordinary 1940s household foil. The seller, who went by "DesertTruth_NM," refunded the $340 and posted a sincere apology. He also joined the club. He's still a member. We don't talk about it.
STATUS: DEBUNKED
ENTRY 004
The Tin-to-Aluminum Transition Conspiracy
When the industry shifted from tin foil to aluminum foil in the early 20th century, some members believe the acoustic properties of tin were deliberately excluded from the new alloy. The theory holds that tin foil's resonance was "too revealing" — of what, exactly, depends on who you ask. Dale says radio frequencies. Agnes said something else. She never wrote it down clearly enough for me to repeat it with a straight face.
STATUS: AGNES BELIEVED THIS
ENTRY 005
The Maumee Bay Resonance
Agnes's final area of research. She believed that pre-war foil, when crinkled at specific points along the shore of Maumee Bay, produced a resonance pattern that didn't match the acoustic environment. She went there seventeen times between January and March 2020. She documented everything. She was very careful. She was the most careful person I've ever known.
STATUS: I DON'T KNOW ANYMORE
